row.name: HPV cervical cancer natural history
row.field_caption: The natural history, risk factors and opportunities for prevention of cervical cancer (HPV: Human Papillomavirus; HR-HPV: high oncogenic risk HPV). The blue boxes depict the natural history of cervical cancer carcinogenesis, from exposure to HPV, to acquisition and persistence of the infection, to pre-invasive lesions that may progress to invasive cervical cancer (ICC). For each step leading to ICC, only a fraction of cases progresses to the next step, whereas the majority will regress. The salmon boxes highlight some of the major risk factors for the initial contact with HPV and for the progression to subsequent steps. The green boxes indicate where opportunities for prevention lie. Reproduced with permission from Tota et al., Prev Med 53: S12-S21, 2011.

row.name: GIS Layers Graphic
row.field_accessible_version: The graphic illustrates the many layers of data that GIS uses to model the real world. At the bottom of the image is a section of the “Real World”, with a river, forest, city, and suburb. Above the real world is a map of elevation in this section of the world. Above this are, from bottom to top, maps of land usage, parcels of land, streets, and political/administrative boundaries.
row.field_caption: GIS can be understood as a “layering” of different types of data, all fundamentally tied to geography, to model real-world phenomena. DCEG scientists collect information on land usage, roads and highways, and many other things to help understand the connections between exposures and cancer.

row.name: GIS Land Use Map
row.field_accessible_version: This GIS land usage map shows an agricultural area with two residences whose locations are indicated by concentric circles representing buffer zones of increasing size: 250 m, 500 m, 750 m, and 1000 m. Colors indicate what each section of land is used for. In this area, the dominant land usages are row crops and pasture/hay. Scientists estimate exposures—such as pesticide exposure—for each residence by calculating how much area each relevant land usage type covers within the different buffer zones.
row.field_caption: This GIS land usage map displays an agricultural area with two residences whose locations are indicated by concentric circles representing buffer zones of increasing size. Scientists estimate exposures—such as pesticide exposure—for each residence by calculating how much area each relevant land usage type covers within the different buffer zones.

row.name: GWAS - Image 1 - mosaicism
row.field_accessible_version: The underlying process of mosaicism is depicted where an individual carrying a complete paternal and maternal chromosome in all cells undergoes a mutational event that clonally expands to become a detectible subset of the total cellular population. This can result in a mosaic loss on the maternal chromosome in only a portion of the cellular population, a mosaic gain on the maternal chromosome, or a mosaic copy neutral loss of heterozygosity.
row.field_caption: The underlying process of mosaicism is depicted where an individual carrying a complete paternal (white) and maternal (black) chromosome in all cells undergoes a mutational event that clonally expands to become a detectible subset of the total cellular population. This can result in a mosaic loss on the maternal chromosome in only a portion of the cellular population (orange), a mosaic gain on the maternal chromosome (yellow), or a mosaic copy neutral loss of heterozygosity (black).

row.name: GWAS image 2 - Deletion - Duplication
row.field_accessible_version: The image depicts changes in the chromosomes, including deletions and duplications. (Illustration by Darryl Leja, NHGRI)
row.field_caption: Researchers have found large, mosaic chromosome abnormalities, including deletions and duplications, in some members of the general population. (Illustration by Darryl Leja, NHGRI)

row.name: GWAS - Image 3 - Detectable clonal mosaic events
row.field_media_image: https://dceg.cancer.gov/PublishedContent/Images/news-events/linkage-newsletter/2017-03/research-publications/Image-3---Freq-of-detectable clonal mosaic events by age and cancer status_WEBsm.jpg
row.field_accessible_version: The figure shows the frequency of detectable clonal mosaic events by age and cancer status (cancer free and cancer diagnosis). The analysis excluded 1,000 individuals with unknown age at DNA collection.
row.field_caption: Frequency of detectable clonal mosaic events by age and cancer status. The analysis excluded 1,000 individuals with unknown age at DNA collection, and 95% confidence intervals are shown. (Jacobs KB, et al. Nat Genet 2012)

row.name: choonsik matt phantoms 300x200
row.field_accessible_version: Dr. Lee, left, and Dr. Mille standing next to their commercially-produced human phantoms. One phantom approximates a grown man, while the other is child-sized.
row.field_caption: Dr. Lee, left, and Dr. Mille with their commercially-produced human phantoms.

row.name: Composite-choonsik and slice
row.field_caption: Dr. Lee examines layers of one of his commercially-produced phantoms. Physical phantoms are composed of stacked layers into which radiation sensors are inserted for testing. Inset: Different colors in the layer approximate various body tissues such as bone or muscle. Small holes for sensors dot the slice; when not in use, the holes are filled with plugs.

row.name: Phantom Family picture - 900x500px
row.field_accessible_version: A series of computational human phantoms, ranging from newborn to adult
row.field_caption: A "family picture" of computational phantoms, modeling a range of ages from newborn to adult.

row.name: Computational Phantoms - Different BMI women - 800x650
row.field_accessible_version: University of Florida/National Cancer Institute) family of hybrid computational phantoms revised to depict larger female body types, categorized by body mass index (BMI). Graphic is based on Geyer et el. PMB 2014.
row.field_caption: Computational phantoms representing a variety of female body types. Drs. Lee and Mille are using 3D printing to customize the body mass index of physical phantoms.

row.name: Breast density figure_small
row.field_caption: Risk of breast cancer according to percent mammographic breast density. Shown on the y-axis are the combined relative risks (95% confidence intervals) from a meta-analysis of percent breast density and its association with incident breast cancer (McCormack, 2006). Representative mammograms of varying degrees of percent mammographic breast density from participants in the BREAST Stamp Project are shown (Gierach, 2014). Figure adapted from Santen, 2005.

row.name: Histologic breast tissue_small
row.field_caption: Investigators use convolutional neural networks (a type of deep learning model) to classify histologic features of breast tissue and examine their relationships with breast density. Green, orange and red represent fat, stroma, and epithelium, respectively. (Bejnordi, 2017)

row.name: TDLU mammograms_small
row.field_caption: Representative full-field digital mammograms from two premenopausal participants in the BREAST Stamp Project. The digital mammogram is acquired with the density phantom in the corner of the image to allow for automated computation of volumetric MBD. Panel A represents a breast biopsy specimen with high TDLU involution. Panel B depicts a breast biopsy specimen with limited TDLU involution, as reflected in the increased number of TDLUs and number of acini within the TDLUs. (Gierach, 2016)

row.name: Cows feeding - 610x407px - with caption

row.name: GIS Crop Map - with caption
row.field_accessible_version: GIS crop maps are used in estimating exposures
row.field_caption: This GIS land usage map displays an agricultural area with two residences whose locations are indicated by concentric circles representing buffer zones of increasing size. Scientists estimate exposures—such as pesticide exposure—for each residence by calculating how much area each relevant land usage type covers within the different buffer zones.

row.name: Gamma camera used with PET scans
row.field_caption: A gamma camera used with positron emission tomography (PET) scans. The patient lies on a table that slides through the PET machine. Cancer cells show up brighter in the picture because they take up more glucose than normal cells.

row.name: Equality vs Equity Graphic from the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation
row.field_accessible_version: Visualizing Infographic depicts Equality versus Equity. Equality shows people of different heights, one in a wheelchair, each trying to ride bikes of the same type and size. Equity depicts those same people riding correctly-sized bikes, with the person formerly shown in a wheelchair riding a bike configured with 3 wheels and hand controls.
row.field_caption: Visualizing Health Equity: One Size Does Not Fit All
